unit.title: Parts of Speech I: Building Strong Sentences
unit.overview: This unit deepens learners’ mastery of core parts of speech—nouns, adjectives, verbs, and pronouns—and shows how they combine to form clear, respectful, and effective sentences. Lessons are short, interactive, and aligned to NaCCA CCP (B7). Enrichment includes AI rewriting tasks, advanced vocabulary, and Ghanaian/Christian moral themes.
competencies: Identify and classify nouns (common, proper, collective, abstract) in short texts.
Use adjectives precisely (order, comparison) to add detail without redundancy.
Demonstrate accurate subject–verb agreement in simple tenses.
Use personal and possessive pronouns to maintain cohesion and avoid repetition.
Write a well‑structured paragraph using varied parts of speech and correct punctuation.
values_morals: Humility and truthfulness in self‑description (avoid boastful language).
Clarity and respect in speech reflect good character (Colossians 4:6).

lessons.title: Nouns Everywhere
objectives: Distinguish common, proper, collective, and abstract nouns.
Capitalise proper nouns correctly (British English conventions).

vocabulary.definition: A noun that names a group (e.g., choir, team).
A noun that names an idea or quality (e.g., honesty, courage).

lessons.moral_link: Name people and places with respect; truthfully represent ideas and groups.

content_blocks.body: Common: market, river • Proper: Volta River, Adabraka JHS • Collective: choir • Abstract: honesty.
Capitalise names of people, towns, rivers, holidays, and institutions.

classify.prompt: Drag each word to the correct noun type.

options: We crossed the volta river near sogakope.
We crossed the Volta River near Sogakope.

lessons.title: Adjectives with Purpose
objectives: Use adjectives for precise description without exaggeration.
Apply the typical order of adjectives before nouns (opinion, size, age, colour, origin, material, purpose).

vocabulary.definition: A word or phrase that describes or limits another word.
Form that compares two (e.g., taller, more honest).
Form that compares three or more (e.g., tallest, most honest).

lessons.moral_link: Describe truthfully; avoid boastful or misleading adjectives.

content_blocks.body: Order example: 'a beautiful small new blue Ghanaian cotton school bag'.
Comparatives: tall → taller; honest → more honest. Superlatives: tallest; most honest.

reorder_words.prompt: Arrange the adjectives in a natural order.
reorder_words.target: a small new blue Ghanaian school bag

mini_quiz.q: Choose the best comparative form: 'Ama is ___ than Kofi.'

ai_task.prompt: Rewrite this sentence to be truthful and concise: 'Our school is the most amazingly incredible best school ever in the universe!'

lessons.title: Verbs and Agreement
objectives: Use simple present, past, and future accurately.
Apply subject–verb agreement with singular/plural subjects and collective nouns.

vocabulary.definition: How an action extends over time (simple, continuous, perfect).
Matching verb form to subject (e.g., 'she walks', 'they walk').

lessons.moral_link: Consistency in speech mirrors integrity in character.

content_blocks.body: Simple tenses: I walk (present), I walked (past), I will walk (future).
Collective nouns in formal British usage often take singular verbs: 'The choir sings well.'

items.text: Tomorrow, we __ (will present/will presents) our poem.

ai_task.prompt: Convert these to simple past: 'I write a letter. They sing a hymn.'

lessons.title: Pronouns for Cohesion
objectives: Use personal, possessive, demonstrative, and reflexive pronouns accurately.

vocabulary.definition: The quality of forming a unified whole; smooth connection of ideas.
When a pronoun could refer to more than one noun.

lessons.moral_link: Be clear and honest; do not confuse your listener.

content_blocks.body: Personal: I, you, he, she, it, we, they • Possessive: my, your, his, her, its, our, their • Demonstrative: this/that/these/those • Reflexive: myself, yourself, etc.

drag_drop.prompt: Match each pronoun to its antecedent in the paragraph.

error_hunt.text: Kofi told Kwame that he should meet him at his desk. They were late.
error_hunt.solution_hint: Repeat the noun when clarity matters: 'Kofi told Kwame to meet Kofi at Kofi’s desk.'

lessons.title: Sentence Building Workshop
objectives: Combine nouns, adjectives, verbs, and pronouns to write clear sentences.
Write a cohesive 5–6 sentence paragraph with correct agreement and punctuation.

vocabulary.definition: Logical connection and consistency of ideas.
A word/phrase that links ideas (e.g., therefore, however, meanwhile).

lessons.moral_link: Use your words to build up, not tear down (Ephesians 4:29).

content_blocks.body: Model paragraph shows topic sentence, details with adjectives and clear pronouns, and a concluding sentence.

scaffold: Topic sentence: Introduce a class activity (e.g., choir practice).
Detail 1: Use one collective noun and a precise verb.
Detail 2: Add two adjectives in natural order.
Detail 3: Use at least one pronoun for cohesion.
Conclusion: Reflect on teamwork or humility.

options: The president visited cape coast castle.
The President visited Cape Coast Castle.

quiz_mcq.q: Which sentence uses adjectives in a natural order?
options: I bought a Ghanaian blue new small bag.
I bought a small new blue Ghanaian bag.

quiz_mcq.q: Choose the sentence with correct agreement.
options: The team win their match today.
The team wins its match today.

quiz_mcq.q: Pick the correct verb form: 'Ama and Kofi __ to school early.'
Which pronoun best replaces the underlined nouns? 'The prefects helped the new pupils. The prefects guided the pupils to their class.'
options: They helped them. They guided them to their class.
He helped them. He guided them to their class.

quiz_mcq.q: Identify the vague pronoun: 'They said it was late.'
Choose the best transition: 'We practised the hymn. ____, we performed before assembly.'

options: The choir sing. Kind. Loud. Church.
The choir sings well; later, it will perform in church.

writing_prompt.prompt: Write a 5–6 sentence paragraph describing a class event (e.g., science fair or sports day). Use at least two adjectives, one collective noun, one pronoun, and correct subject–verb agreement.

speaking_task.prompt: Give a 30‑second oral report about your class activity, using respectful register and clear pronouns.

criteria.name: Content & Requirements
criteria.descriptor: Meets all language targets (adjectives, noun types, pronouns, agreement).

criteria.name: Grammar & Mechanics
criteria.descriptor: Capitalisation, punctuation, verb forms are correct.

criteria.name: Cohesion & Transitions
criteria.descriptor: Logical flow with helpful linking words.
